dialog.line: Now let's make a new medical treatment for cancer.
Nanoscale particles can be engineered to carry drugs to the area of the body they’re needed most.
We’re going to make tiny packages that destroy cancer cells using nanoparticles of gold, an anti-cancer drug and an antibody protein that recognizes cancer cells.
The first step is to mix two chemical solutions to create tiny gold particles.
Find the weighing scales.
Great.
Now weigh out 0.1g of chloroauric acid powder (gold salt) and mix it with distilled water to form a solution. And then do the same with 0.1g of sodium citrate.
And then do the same with 0.5g of sodium citrate.
Now take the two solutions to the Hotplate Stirrer for mixing.
Heat the chloroauric acid solution, add a magnetic stir bar and then pour in the sodium citrate solution.
The sodium citrate reduces gold ions into gold atoms.
The mixture turns red as the gold atoms cluster into nanoparticles.
The next step is to measure your gold particles with the Dynamic Light Scattering machine.
That’s it. Put a sample of the solution into the machine.
A laser blasts light into the sample and the machine records the light scattered by particles in the solution and calculates their size.
Your particles are 50nm in diameter. That’s perfect. Particles this size will be able to enter a cancer cell.
Now head back to the hotplate stirrer to prepare an anti-cancer nanomedicine.
First we need to add an anti-cancer drug.
The drug is called doxorubicin.
Then add chitosan - a liquid containing long polymer molecules, and give the solution a good stir.
The polymer molecules have linked together, wrapping up gold nanoparticles and the anti-cancer drug into small packages.
Now you need to purify the solution. Find the dialysis cassette.
Inject the solution into the membrane bag inside the cassette and then place it in some distilled water.
The excess drug is small enough to pass through the membrane leaving just the larger gold-drug-polymer particles inside. This purifies the solution!
Now we just need to add a final outer layer to the nanoparticles – an antibody, a protein that recognizes cancer cell.
These linker molecules bind to the outside of the nanoparticle and enable us to add the final ingredient – an antibody.
Now you do it!
To make a dose of our cancer fighting nanomedicine, we need to mix the solutions in the correct order. Click to mix the different solutions.

Once injected into the body the nanomedicine is small enough to go undetected by the body’s defence mechanisms. The antibody you added binds with receptors on a cancer cell and the nanomedicine is smuggled inside.
Enzymes in the cancer cell degrade the polymer capsule and release the drug and gold nanoparticles. The drug then damages the DNA of the cancer cell.
When the patient is exposed to near-infrared light, the gold nanoparticles absorb the energy and convert it into heat, which also helps kill the cancer cell.
Nanoparticle treatments like this are currently being tested and offer huge potential in the fight against cancer.
